content:
This is a great clash, but your tests and validators are not well-chosen.

I just got this in a clash and got 100% on test cases, but 50% on validators because I mistakenly checked the days from '(firstweekday...totaldays)' instead of '(firstweekday...totaldays+firstweekday)'

The reason it worked 100% on tests is because 2/4 tests start on day 0 (so my mistake is null) and then the other two just happen to give the same result.

Here's my Ruby code, it would be good if you could make another test/validator pair that my code will fail for:

firstweekday = gets.to_i
totaldays = gets.to_i
n = gets.to_i
w = []
n.times do
  name, weekday = gets.split
  w << weekday.to_i
end
puts (firstweekday...totaldays).count{|day| w.none?{ day % 7 == _1 }}

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a fun and engaging, short programming activity. Certain languages will have a clear advantage, but that is okay.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Funny premise for a solvable challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice problem :)

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: it isn't well explained, and might need more than 15 minutes to be solved.

One thing that worries me about this puzzle is having to calculate the total_amount of days, it's pretty easy if the language has some datetime package in the standard repository. But I don't know if asking the user to know that is too much or if this will be a problem for languages without it, one solution could be providing the initial weekday and the total amount of days. If possible I'd rather leave the dates though

Input
* Please add ", separated by a space" after "they hate".

Thanks.

Is there a specific part that isn't well explained? How can I make it more clear?

if you use a loop based approach it should be doable in under 5 minutes


firstweekday = int(input())
totaldays = int(input())
n = int(input())
hated_weekdays = [int(input().split()[1])for i in range(n)]
none_hated_weekdays = 0
for i in range(totaldays):
    if firstweekday not in hated_weekdays:
        none_hated_weekdays += 1
    firstweekday += 1
    if firstweekday == 7:
        firstweekday = 0

print(none_hated_weekdays)
Thanks! I inverted test 2 and validator 2, now it catches the error in the test cases.
